loan.name: Melba

texts.en: Melba is 48 years of age, married and blessed with ninth children. She is involved in the livestock business, particularly raising hogs. Her net income, every three months, is 7,000 per hog. She is requesting a loan of 15,000 PHP to purchase additional livestock feed for her hogs. She would like to continue receiving loans to grow her business, and generate profits to invest in the future.

loan.use: to purchase additional livestock feed for her hogs

loan.name: Joseph

texts.en:
Joseph's business is doing well and he is very happy. He repaid his previous loan well and in good time and has applied for a second loan that he plans to use to buy milk to sell.
With the profit that Joseph will get from his loan, he wants to open another shop to sell milk. In the future, he wants to own four milk shops in Kiambu town.

loan.use: to buy milk

loan.name: Pacita

texts.en:
Pacita is married. Pacita is 54 years old and lives in Gil Sanchez, Labason, Zamboanga del Norte.
Pacita owns a general store to earn a living and has had this business for three years. Each month, she earns 3000 PHP doing this type of work. She has requested a loan of 7000 PHP to purchase more stock for her general store.
Pacita has been a member of PMPC for two years. In the future, Pacita hopes to expand her business.

loan.use: to purchase more stock for her general store.

location.town: Gil Sanchez, Labason, Zamboanga del Norte

loan.name: Tomas

texts.en:
Tomas is a married man. He has two children aged 2 years and 5 years. He describes himself as innovative and patient. He operates a retail store where he sells spare parts. He has been involved in this business for five years. His business is located at a densely populated and busy area. He describes his biggest business challenge to be the high cost of goods sold.
Tomas will use the Kes 20,000 loan to buy more spare parts. His business goal is to venture into running his own garage within five years.

loan.use: To buy more spare parts.

loan.name: Anonymous
loan.use: To construct more taps and renovate/secure the business area.

loan.name: Mary Elaine

texts.en:
Mary Elaine is a married woman with two children. Mary Elaine is 31 years old, residing at Dela Paz, Clarin, Misamis Occidental, Philippines. Mary Elaine owns and operates a farm, planting & harvesting rice for sale to earn a living and she's been six years in this business.
Each month, she earns 5,000 PHP doing this type of business. She requested a loan of 15,000 PHP to purchase additional fertilizer and seeds, seedlings & young crops to raise. Mary Elaine has been a member of GDMPC for almost a year. In the future, Mary Elaine wants to make improvements to her house and see her children finish their studies.

loan.use: to purchase fertilizer and seeds, seedlings & young crops to raise.

loan.name: Irenea

texts.en:
Irenea is married with four children. Irenea is 53 years old and lives in Mauswagon, Liloy, Zamboanga del Norte.
Irenea owns a sari-sari (variety) store to earn a living and has had this business for 20 years. Each month, she earns 2000 PHP doing this type of work. She has requested a loan of 12,000 PHP to purchase more stock for her general store.
Irenea has been a member of PMPC for two years. In the future, Irenea hopes to expand her business.

loan.use: to purchase more stock for her general store.

loan.name: Claudia

texts.en:
Claudia is a 51-year-old married woman with four children. She and her husband are both farmers. They own and till a piece of land in their town in Trinidad, Bohol. According to Claudia, they have been growing and selling rice for 10 years. Each month, they earn 6,000 PHP per month doing this farming. Claudia does her best to support her family.
Claudia has requested this loan to purchase fertilizers and pay for labor. Claudia hopes to achieve an abundant harvest.

loan.use: to purchase fertilizer and pay for labor.

loan.name: Esther

texts.en:
Esther is 26 years old. She distributes polythene bags in Voi town. She is a married mother of two children. She has been doing this business for the last one year and she is doing great.
This is Estherâ€™s first business loan from KADET LTD. She plans to purchase more polythene bags to resell to her customers.
She will use the proceeds to buy a piece of land to construct a permanent house on. She hopes to excel in her business.

loan.use: to purchase more polythene bags.

loan.name: Dorce

texts.en:
Dorce is a 42-year-old widow who is living with three children, they are: Jack, 19 and graduated from Senior High School; Fredy, 12 and studying at the 2nd grade of Junior High School; Kartika, 10, studying at the 4th grade of Elementary School.
Since the death of her husband, Dorce automatically took on the responsible to support her children. She struggles in covering her children's educational fees. Prior to running a kiosk business, Dorce used to sell vegetables at her house. She started her kiosk business in 2009.
Dorce plans to improve her business by selling vegetables at her kiosk, as the community members around her residence usually buy vegetables from the roundsman. Currently Dorce is seeking additional capital to improve her business. Her neighbor suggested to her to apply for a loan from TLM.
Dorce is requesting a loan of IDR 3,000,000 from TLM to add a greater variety of products, e.g., biscuits, soft drinks, snacks and fresh vegetables as well at her kiosk. Dorce really hopes that she can receive the loan soon.

loan.use: to purchase a variety of products, e.g., biscuits, soft drinks, snacks and fresh vegetables.

loan.name: Gloria

texts.en:
Gloria is married to Nestor, a farmer in the village of Villa Concepcion. Gloria is a responsible mother, who raises hogs in order to acquire an income and to lift her family out of poverty. Gloria usually raises hogs to fatten and breed. She has been doing this for more than two years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP for each hog disposed.
Gloria wants to improve her hog-selling business and is in need of additional capital so she is now asking for a loan of P20,000 to buy additional piglets to raise and feed for sustainability.
In the future, she would like to make stronger her small business and continuously acquire profits from it.

loan.use: to buy additional piglets to raise and feed for sustainability

loan.name: Paul

texts.en:
Paul is a married man. He has four children. He describes himself as honest, intelligent and obedient. He operates a motorcycle providing transportation. He has been involved in this business for four years. His business is located at a resiential area and his primary customers are residents. He describes his biggest business challenge to be the high cost of fuel.
Paul will use the Kes 20,000 loan to add to his savings and buy another motorbike. Paul's business goal is to own many motorbikes within five years.

loan.use: To add to his savings and buy another motorbike.

loan.name: Rebaz

texts.en:
Rebaz is a 23-year-old Iraqi man with a bakery. His bakery has been generating income for him for the past five years, allowing him to contribute to the living expenses of his family. Although he is single and living in a multi-generation household, he plays an active role in supporting the household.
In the past Rebaz took a loan from Relief International - Iraq, which allowed him to buy a large mixer machine for making the bread dough. After successfully repaying the first loan, Rebaz took a loan of 1,200 USD, which he would like to use to renovate the interior of the bakery. He plans to remove the smoky built-up residue from the walls and make the area cleaner and brighter.
Rebaz is under 30, qualifying for a youth loan.

loan.use: to renovate the interior of his bakery

loan.name: Shano

texts.en:
Shano is 22 years young and lives in a typical Iraqi household setting, where 3 generations share the space and share the work, each contributing to making the house a home. In the guest living room, the family's possessions are neatly displayed and decorated to showcase a good status as the result of generations of work.
As Shano was becoming an adult, it was time for her to also contribute to the family's living expenses. Educated to the primary level, she has been meeting this duty since 2008 by doing sewing work in her home.
In the past, Shano applied for, received, and successfully repaid the first loan she took from Relief International-Iraq. She used this loan to improve her working area. Shano now took a loan of 1,500 USD from RI-Iraq to buy raw materials.
Shano is under 30, qualifying for a youth loan.

loan.use: to purchase raw materials for her sewing works.

loan.name: Peninah

texts.en:
Peninah is a resident and a farmer in Kitale, Western Kenya, where she has been producing and selling mainly maize, vegetables, tomatoes, and milk for the local market. She is married with two children aged 12 and 8 years. She has been in farming for 3 years and employs two farmhands.
Peninah has requested a loan of 30,000 Kenya shillings (KES) from Juhudi Kilimo to help her venture into poultry farming by buying poultry birds. She says there is a ready market for poultry products and she wants to exploit the opportunity and raise her financial income.
She notes lack of capital and unreliable rain as the main challenges.

loan.use: To buy poultry birds.

loan.name: Rosalin

texts.en:
Rosalin is a 41-year-old lady who is married to Robinson, a 41-year-old man. They are blessed with four children: Johan, 17, is studying in the third grade of Senior High School; Afliana, 14, is studying in the first grade of Senior High School; Michael, 9, is studying in the third grade of Elementary School; and Presley, 2.
Rosalin is a seamstress. She has been running the business for two years. Rosalin sews school uniforms, blouses, skirts, curtains and party dresses. Prior to running the business, Rosalin worked in Malaysia for years. She returned to Indonesia in 2007.
Even though her current business is running well, Rosalin wants to initiate another business: a food stall business. She is expecting that from the new business she will be able to generate more income for her family. Therefore, she needs a loan of IDR 4,000,000. She would like to spend the loan on food stall equipment and ingredients. Rosalin is hoping that TLM will approve her loan application soon.

loan.use: To purchase food stall equipment and ingredients

loan.name: Yon

texts.en:
Mrs. Yon, 55, is a single parent who has been living with 7 children since she divorced her husband. She tries hard to earn a living.
Yon is a humble farmer as well as a grocery seller from her house. Usually, she generates around $2.50 per day from her selling business. However, this low income canâ€™t cover Mrs. Yonâ€™s daily expenses. Accordingly, three of her children decided to work in various jobs: an apprentice goldsmith, a sewing staff person, and a construction worker. They always share income with their mother in order to better their living conditions.
At the present, Yonâ€™s family doesnâ€™t own any vehicles for use, so every day her employed children take taxi services to work. Therefore, Yon is looking for some funds to purchase a motorcycle for her three children to use in commuting to work. With the remaining funds, she will buy merchandise to sustain her business.
For her prospect, she wishes to build a suitable store and sell many types of products to satisfy local people.

loan.use: to purchase a motorcycle for her three children to use in commuting to work.

loan.name: Beth

texts.en:
Beth is a 38-year-old woman. She is married and a mother of two children, and she owns a butchery and rental houses in Kinoo. Her husband supports her with additional income from his teaching job. Beth has been in the business for five years now and gets a monthly income of 20,000 Kenya shillings (KES).
This will be Bethâ€™s first loan with KADET LTD. She plans to use the entire loan to purchase more stock for her butchery. With the profit that she earns, she will pay school fees. In the future, she wants to be able to build two store buildings by mid-year.

loan.use: To buy meat for resale.

loan.name: Nelson

texts.en:
Nelson is from the village of Panta-on, Ozamiz City, Misamis Occidental. He is 48 years old. Nelson is married and has four children.
To make a living, Nelson has a business planting and harvesting crops. Nelson has been engaged in his business for over 15 years and earns approximately 4,000 Philippines pesos (PHP) a month from these activities. Nelson is requesting a loan of 3,250 PHP, which will be used to purchase fertilizer such as manure.
In 2010, Nelson joined GDMPC to seek for financial assistance as an additional investment to his business. He plans to use the income generated to expand his business and house improvement.

loan.use: to purchase fertilizer such as manure.

loan.name: Noel

texts.en:
Noel is from Panta-On, Ozamiz City, Misamis Occidental. He is married with one child and he is 23 years old.
Noel plants and harvests root crops to sell to earn a living and he has been in this business for three years. Each month, he earns 3,000 Philippines pesos (PHP) doing this type of business. He requested a loan of 3,900 PHP to purchase fertilizer.
Since 2010, Noel has been a member of GDMPC. In the future, Noel wants to build a house and to finish funding the education of his child.

loan.use: to purchase fertilizer.

loan.name: Andrea

texts.en:
Andrea engages in cooking and selling street food and different kinds of vegetables, to earn additional income. She has been in this business for almost seven years earning a net profit of only P500 a day.
She aims to improve her business to increase her income to cover all their household expenditures and support her children's needs. Due to inadequate capital, she is asking for a loan of P15,000 to buy different kinds of vegetables and ingredients (egg, hot-dog, pork and "adiddas") to be cooked and sell in the village.
She needs to work hard and strive harder to achieve her goals. She hopes that in the future, her business will grow. She believes that nothing is impossible to a person who has strong faith and determination.

loan.use: to buy different kinds of vegetables and ingredients (egg, hot-dog, pork and "adiddas") to be cooked and sell in the village

loan.name: Shadya

texts.en:
Shadya is a shy, young mother, living with her child and husband in a one-room, very modest home in Iraq. She also uses the warm and welcoming room to do her sewing work. With this work, she is able to ensure that her family's clothing needs are met and to generate a small amount of income (by doing small jobs for her customers).
Shadya is seeking a loan in the amount of $1,200 from Relief International - Iraq to purchase additional fabric and raw materials so that she can work on larger sewing and tailoring jobs and in turn contribute more to her family's income.
Shadya is under 30, qualifying for a youth loan.
Based on the political and social challenges of lending in Iraq, personally identifiable information about this borrower has been altered for her protection. RI-Iraq appreciates Kiva lenders' consideration of these challenges and encourages lenders to continue their support for Iraqi borrowers.

loan.use: to purchase additional fabric and raw materials

loan.name: Mercedita

texts.en:
Mercedita, 45, is the mother of three children. Mercedita has one year experience raising pigs, an activity that allowed her to raise all her children. She is determine to works hard to lift her family from poor living.
Mercedita is requesting a loan of PHP15,000 to buy feed and vaccine for her pigs. She dreams with seeing her business grow and to have a good estate to leave her children good economic stability and quality of life.

loan.use: to buy feed and vaccine for her pigs

loan.name: Anonymous
loan.use: to purchase construction materials in order to expand her house.

loan.name: Selly

texts.en:
Selly is a 28-year-old, married woman with one child. Her child is 7 years old.

To earn a living, she works as a farmer in Kitale, Kenya. She explains that she has been farming for four years and currently operates her farming business with the help of one farmhand. She grows maize, beans, and tomatoes to sell at the local market. She notes that price fluctuations in crops and high input costs are her primary business challenges.

Selly is requesting a loan in the amount of 52,000 KES from Juhudi Kilimo to buy and insure a dairy cow. She says that the dairy cow will provide her family with milk for consumption and for re-sale purposes, and will thereby generate additional income to help meet her family's needs. In the future, she hopes to expand her business.

loan.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow

loan.name: Irene

texts.en: Irene is a married woman. She has two children who are 9 months and 4 years old. She describes herself as honest, God-fearing and innovative. She operates a green grocery where she sells vegetables and fruit. She has been involved in this business for two years. Her business is located in a residential area. She describes her biggest business challenge to be the high cost of vegetables and fruit. She will use the Kes 20,000 loan to buy more stock to sell. Her business goal is to run a well-stocked green grocery within five years.

loan.use: To buy more vegetables and fruit to sell.

loan.name: Jackson

texts.en:
Jackson is twenty-nine years old. He is married with six children, and a livestock trader in Loitoktok. He has been in the business for five years and gets a monthly income of 14,000 shillings.
This will be Jacksonâ€™s first loan from KADET LTD. He plans to use the entire loan to purchase more cows and goats to sell, using the profit to expand his livestock business.
In the future he wants to do well in the livestock and farming industry

loan.use: To buy more cows and goats to sell.

loan.name: Cynthia

texts.en: Cynthia is 30 years old and married with two children aged two and 11. For the past six years, she has sold used clothes to earn a living, and now employs one person. Since she joined Faulu Kenya she has been able to expand her business and hopes to be financially stable in the future. She has applied for 50,000 Kenyan Shillings to buy trousers, dresses and jackets to resell.

loan.use: To buy trousers, dresses and jackets.

loan.name: Guldarbubu

texts.en:
Guldarbubu is 63 years old, married, and has raised five children. The main activity of her family is fattening and reselling of cattle. Having started already in 1993 with as sum of 20,000 som (KGS), the farm now brings in around 7,000 som (KGS) per month. Currently Guldarbubu's farm has one dairy cow and ten sheep.
With the aim of increasing the number of cattle, Guldarbubu turned to the organization "Bai Tushum & Partners" for a loan in the amount of 70,000 som (KGS) for the purchase of additional cattle. This will enable Guldarbubu to enlarge her farm, and according to opinion this it a very good investment.

loan.use: to purchase livestock

loan.name: Gladys

texts.en:
Gladys is a mother of two children aged two and one years old. She has been in farming for the past four years. Her farm produces milk, maize, beans and vegetables for the local market in Kitale, Western Kenya. Gladys runs her farm with the help of one farmhand. Her farm is her sole source of income.
Glady has requested a loan of 30,000 KES from Juhudi Kilimo to help her buy poultry to expand into poultry farming. She hopes to make better returns from the business and use the profits to expand her dairy farming in the future. She believes she will be able to cope with the challenge of diseases which is rampant in poultry farming.

loan.use: To buy poultry.

loan.name: Raisa

texts.en:
Raisa has decided to take out another loan since she needs to heat her greenhouse and add a double layer of plastic sheeting as additional insurance against a freeze. This way she can start selling earlier in the year for better prices.
Thanks to her previous loan which allowed her to build an additional greenhouse, Raisa now has five greenhouses.
Last summer, at the end of the season, Raisa divorced her husband. Because of this, she had to run the entire business herself. It was hard, and therefore she received less income than the previous year. But Raisa has an adult son who helps his mother on the farm. Raisa takes care of her elderly parents who live with her.

loan.use: to heat her greenhouse and add a double layer of plastic sheeting.

loan.name: Srun

texts.en:
Mrs. Srun is a 26-year-old mother of two who lives in the Prey Chor district. She is a local farmer who owns a few plots of farmland for growing rice crops two seasons of the year. She has a common-law relationship with her husband, aged 29, who is skilled in making and repairing iron tools.
Srun would like to take out a loan to purchase iron to support her husbandâ€™s business. Her husband will use the iron to make tools and other items as needed by his customers. Srun hopes that her familyâ€™s business will improve so they can improve their standard of living.

loan.use: to purchase iron to support her husbandâ€™s business.

loan.name: Son

texts.en: Ms Son is 33 years old with two school-aged children. She manages a small grocery store. Her shop opened seven years ago and provides a stable income for her family. Participating in our credit program in 2008, she found it suitable for her business. Currently, she wants a loan of 8,736,000 Vietnamese dong to buy more products to sell for the Tet holiday.

loan.use: to buy more products to sell for the Tet holiday.

loan.name: Margaret

texts.en:
Margaret lives in the city of Kampala, Uganda. She is married with five children, all of whom are in school. She also takes care of additional family members (a sister). Margaret has a business selling cereals (ground nuts). She has been in this business for four years, and works six days out of every week. Margaret sells her products from home, both wholesale and retail.
Margaret has requested a loan of 1,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more bags of ground nuts. The main business challenges for Margaret are seasonality and transportation. Her goals and aspirations for her business are to start going to villages for cereals and also to build her own rental houses. Margaret lives in a home that she owns, where she has access to electricity and running water. Her major monthly expenses include her utilities, school fees and food for the family.

loan.use: To buy more bags of ground nuts.

loan.name: Cleophas

texts.en:
Cleophas is a resident of Kitale where he lives with his family of five children, four of whom are in school. He says farming has been his main source of income.
Cleophas has requested a loan of 90,000 KES from Juhudi Kilimo to start a poultry farm. This is his third loan with Juhudi Kilimo. His first two loans were for 30,000 KES and 60,000 KES. He says he wants to start a massive poultry project and hopes to succeed based on information he has gathered on poultry and the ready market within the Kitale region for poultry products. He plans to build a large chicken coop for 60,000 KES and buy birds for 30,000 KES.
Cleophas says poultry diseases are a major problem, but surmountable with proper planning and hygiene.

loan.use: To build chicken coops and buy poultry for resale.

loan.name: Cresent

texts.en: Crescent is a married man. He has eight children ranging in age from three to 22 years. He describes herself to be God-fearing. He operates a farm where he sells kale.He has been involved in this business for four years. His business is located in a residential area and his primary customers are the local residents. He describes his biggest business challenge to be the high cost of kale seeds. He will use the Kes 20,000 loan to buy kale seeds. His business goal is to plant all types of vegetables within five years.

loan.use: To buy more kale seeds.

loan.name: 06. ÄÃ´ng Vá»‡ Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Dung operates a food stall selling roll of pork. She is requesting a loan to purchase pork to make roll of pock to resell.
Dung is 54 years old and she is married and has 2 children. Dung is the group leader of the 06.09.06-ÄÃ´ng Vá»‡ solidarity group, which consists of 5 members. Dung lives with 2 dependents in Thanh Hoa city, an urban town in Thanh Hoa province.
This is Dung's first loan with Thanh Hoa Fund of Poor Women. Dung has been involved in this business for more than 10 years. The main hardship that Dung faces in her business is the lack of capital. In the future, Dung hopes for her children to find good jobs, for her business to do well, and for her family to be healthy and happy.

loan.use: to purchase pork to make roll of pork to resell.

loan.name: Mariya

texts.en:
Mariya is divorced and has two children. After college she had several different jobs. However, she soon realized that her best opportunity would be to have her own business. In 1996, she was able to start a small business selling womenâ€™s clothing.
Mariya is a very friendly, persevering and hard-working lady. Being a sociable person, she relates easily with her clients. Every time you pass by her kiosk you can find her talking to a new person who will most likely end up buying something.
Mariya is requesting a loan of 6,000 grivnas to increase seasonal inventories. She is planning to purchase a variety of suits, jackets, coats and sweaters in bulk for further retail sale. The loan will be beneficial to her business by promoting its expansion which will further assist Mariya in meeting her household expenses and allow her to set aside some savings for future needs.

loan.use: to increase seasonal inventories

loan.name: Noah

texts.en: Noah is 25 years old and is married, with two children. He sells second-hand shoes to earn a living. He has been in the business for 3 years and has employed one person. He describes his business environment as competitive because many people do the same business. Since he joined Faulu Kenya he has been able to save his income. He hopes to expand his business and be financially stable in the future. He has applied for 50,000 Kenya Shillings to buy second-hand shoes to sell.

loan.use: To buy second hand shoes to sell

loan.name: 06.09.01 ÄÃ´ng Vá»‡ Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Huyá»n has a retail business sellingÂ incense and ghost money. She is requesting a loan to purchase votive objects to resell.
Huyá»n is 30 years old and she is married and has one child. Huyá»n is the group leader of the 06.09.01-ÄÃ´ng Vá»‡ solidarity group, which consists of 5 members. Huyá»n lives with 1 dependent. in Thanh Hoa city, an urban town in Thanh Hoa province.
In 2010, Huyá»n joined Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women to improve her business. Huyá»n has successfully repaid 2 loans from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. Huyá»n has been involved in this business for more than 10 years. The main hardship that Huyá»n faces in her business is the lack of capital.
With her business profit, Huyá»n hopes for her children to do well in school, to make enough money to provide for her kids, and for her family to be healthy and happy.

loan.use: to purchase votive objects to resell.

loan.name: Roseline

texts.en:
Roseline is a resident farmer in Kitale. She is 34 years old and is married. She has four children between 16 and 9 years old. She has carried out farming for 15 years, with her produce of milk, maize, vegetables and beans going to the local market.
Roseline has requested a loan of 62,400 KES from Juhudi Kilimo to buy and insure a dairy cow. She says this will boost her farming income and provide milk for family consumption. She says the knowledge in dairy farming acquired with her 15 years of practice has helped her. She now appreciates the need for better breeds of cows. She reiterates that she will buy a good breed to ensure a high yield from her dairy cow. She adds the income generated will improve her family living standards.
She, however, laments of the high costs and rampant animal diseases.

loan.use: To buy and insure a dairy cow

loan.name: Nimol

texts.en:
Nimol, 40, resides with her husband and three children in Kampong Chhnang Province, Cambodia. She has been running a business of carrying clothes to sell around the village for over two years and is successful in her career. Her husband is a wood trader. One of her children is a construction worker.
In order to improve her business, Nimol is requesting a loan of USD 1000 to purchase a new motorbike for carrying her clothes to sell. In the future, she would like to expand her business and support her children's studies until they get bachelor's degrees.

loan.use: to purchase a new motorbike for carrying her clothes to sell

loan.name: Sophan

texts.en:
Sophan, age 25, is a garment worker. Her husband is a taxi driver who transports garment workers to work via a tricycle vehicle to the factory where they work. Since her husband's vehicle is broken down, Sophan is requesting a loan of USD 500 to pay for vehicle repairs. with the repairs completed, her husband's transportation service will run smoothly and attract more customers.
In the future, she would like to purchase a truck, which would allow her husband more effectively to carry garment workers to the factory and to generate more income for the family. In addition, she plans to make repairs to the family house and to support her children's education.
Sophan resides with her husband and two children in Kampong Chhnang Province, Cambodia.

loan.use: to pay for vehicle repairs for her husband's tricycle transportation vehicle

loan.name: Sarah

texts.en:
Sarah owns and operates a retail hardware shop. She has been in this business for four years, and she works in her shop six days out of every week.
Sarah has requested a loan of 2,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO. She will use the loan funds to buy more bags of cement, iron sheets, nails, and barbed wire. She also generates additional income by selling rice.
Her primary business challenges include thieves and the difficulties involved in transportation. Her goals and aspirations for her business are to own a fully-stocked hardware shop. She also plans to build a house for the family.
Sarah and her husband live in a rented home with their five children in Kampala. They have access to electricity and piped water. Her major monthly expenses include school fees and food for the family. All five of her children are enrolled in school. Sarah also takes care of her sister and brother.

loan.use: to buy bags of cement, nails, iron sheets, and barbed wire to sell in her hardware shop

loan.name: Chavasinya

texts.en:
Chavasinya, age 40, is a farmer in Kitake. He has five solid years of experience in farming. Maize, vegetables, and beans are his main produce, which he sells at the local market. He also trades in livestock in addition to active farming.
He and his wife have six children, the eldest of whom is 12 years old. The youngest is a nine-month-old baby.
Chavasinya has requested a loan of 30,000 KES from Juhudi Kilimo in order to buy poultry birds. This will enable him to venture into poultry farming, which will be a valuable new source of income, particularly since his farming endeavors face the ongoing obstacles of the high costs of inputs and unreliable rains. He hopes his new business will grow and and enable him to embrace modern techniques in poultry farming. He intends in this way to exploit the economies of scale that present the main challenge for most small farmers to do their farming with limited capacity.

loan.use: to buy poultry birds

loan.name: Muthimbe

texts.en: Muthimbe, 70 years old, is married and has 10 children. She has operated a retail shop for 17 years and describes her business environment as good because there is limited competition. Muthimbe earns extra income from her farming activities. Since she joined Faulu Kenya, she has been able to grow her business and she hopes to expand it in the future. Muthimbe has applied for a loan of KES 40,000 to buy maize flour, sugar and rice.

loan.use: To buy maize flour, sugar and rice

loan.name: Kunthea

texts.en: Kunthea, 30, is married and lives with her husband and two children in Kampong Chhnang Province, Cambodia. She is a garment worker and her husband is a sculptor. In order to improve her family's income, Kuthea is requesting a loan of US $700 to purchase a piece of farmland for growing rice. In the future, she would like to sell breakfast food at home to generate more income. Moreover, she plans to build a new house and support her children to study at higher levels of education.

loan.use: to purchase a piece a farmland for growing rice

loan.name: Fatuma

texts.en:
Fatuma lives in the city of Kampala, Uganda. She is single and has 5 children, all of whom are in school. She also takes care of additional family members (her late sister's children). Fatuma has operated a beauty salon business for 6 years, and she works 6 days out of every week. She sells her products in a retail shop.

Fatuma has requested a loan of 1,500,000 UGX from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more boxes of cream relaxers, braids and weaves. The main business challenges for Fatuma include thieves and seasonality. Her goals and aspirations are to own a bridal salon and to build her own house. Fatuma lives in a home that she rents; she has access to electricity and piped water. Her major monthly expenses include rent, school fees and food for the family.

loan.use: To buy more boxes of cream relaxers, weaves and braids

loan.name: Gaudencia

texts.en:
Gaudecia has been engaged in farming for 10 years. The farm produces eggs, beans, milk, and vegetables for the local market. Gaudecia runs a hotel located near the local market for additional income. She currently employs one farmhand.
She and her husband have four children. The eldest is 12 years old and the youngest is a two-month-old baby.
Gaudencia has requested a loan of 41,600 KES from Juhudi Kilimo to buy and insure a dairy cow. She says this will boost her farm's milk output and provide supplementary nutrition for her family's meals. She reports that animal diseases are an ongoing challenge, but she has high expectations. She adds that she will use a major part of the increased income to improve her business and raise the family's living standards.

loan.use: to buy and insure a dairy cow

loan.name: Sovann

texts.en: Sovann, 47, is widowed and resides with one school-aged child in Kampong Chhnang Province, Cambodia. She has been running a business selling all kinds of drinks in the market for over ten years and is successful in her career. In order to increase her income, Sovann is requesting a loan of US $1,000 to purchase more drinks to sell in order to generate more profit to support the family. In the future, she would like to expand her business, renovate her house and support her child to study at higher levels.

loan.use: to purchase more drinks to sell

loan.name: Rufina

texts.en:
Rufina, 61, is a resident of Silang,Cavite, Philippines. She is married to Feliciano, an electrician, with whom she has three children, all married. Rufina and her husband manage their own household while operating the business. Rufina works hard to continually provide income for the family's everyday expenses.
Rufina operates a variety store which, in the Philippines, is basically a small convenience store, which retails groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, PHP 5 worth of cooking oil, or an egg. Rufina earns an income by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling by the piece. Her store is located adjacent to her house and her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of PHP 300 in sales every day.
To help her continue operations of her business, Rufina is requesting a PHP 17,000 loan. She will be using the loan to buy groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory. Rufina expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.
Rufina hopes to be able to expand soon, just as she fervently hopes that her family has a better future. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members weekly to share stories of her work and to draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.
* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay microfinance loans.

loan.use: To pay for grocery items and products needed in her business.

loan.name: Anonymous
loan.use: to pay school fees for his children

loan.name: Jane

texts.en:
Jane, age 40, sells used shoes to earn a living. She has been in the business for three years and describes her business environment as competitive because so many other people are engaged in the same business.
Since she joined Faulu Kenya, she has been able to improve her living standards. She hopes to expand her business in the future.
She has applied for a loan in the amount of 30,000 Kenya Shillings in order to buy shoes to offer for sale. She is single and has one child.

loan.use: to buy shoes to offer for sale

loan.name: Olivia

texts.en:
Olivia, age 35, is the hard-working single mother of three children. She started as a local gin distiller and saved her money to build the houses that she now offers for rent. Her primary challenge is when tenants do not pay on time.
Her family goal is to see her children educated, and her business goal is to expand her business to new markets.
Olivia intends to use the loan to renovate her rental houses.

loan.use: to renovate her rental houses

loan.name: Hassan

texts.en:
Hassan is a 37-year-old man. He is married and a father of seven children. They live in Taiz, Yemen. His educational background is Bachelor of Commerce.
Hassan's main business is a grocery store selling food items, other daily service needs and gas cylinders. He started his business two years ago and it is the only source of income for him and his family. He has attracted more clients and confined people. His business has continued running successfully and is more profitable.
Due to the current bad situations in Yemen, he has less profit from his enterprise and his customers are decreasing. Hassan took a loan of 100,000 YER from AMB to expand his business by purchasing more grocery items.
In the future, he hopes to expand his business to purchase another shop and make it a gas cylinder store and also buy a car for transporting his business items.

loan.use: to buy more grocery items to sell.

loan.name: Daisy

texts.en:
This is Daisy, 32 years old, resident of Silang, Cavite Philippines. She is married to Napoleon, a driver. She is the mother of one child. By the grace of God, Daisy has managed to support her child's schooling. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for her everyday expenses.
Daisy oversees operations of their tricycle transportation business. They have one unit of tricycles that carries up to four passengers to their destination within the community. The tricycle driver then remits a boundary (daily quota) each day to her. In her business the regular customers are the local community. She earns a minimum of Php 300 every day.
To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a Php17, 000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy spare parts, accessories, and also for the maintenance of her motorcycle. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.
Daisy dreams to be able to give her child a good and high quality education through all her hard work on her business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her work every week, where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.
* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loan.use: To pay for the spare parts and maintenance of their tricycle unit

loan.name: Anonymous
loan.use: to buy both layers and broilers for her poultry project.

loan.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth is married with eight children. Elizabeth is 53 years old and lives in Mauswagon, Liloy, Zamboanga del Norte.
Elizabeth owns a general store to earn a living and has had this business for two years. Each month, she earns 3,000 PHP doing this type of work. She has requested a loan of 5,000 PHP to purchase more stock for her general store.
Elizabeth has been a member of PMPC this year 2011. In the future, Elizabeth hopes to expand her business.

loan.use: to purchase more stock for her general store

loan.name: Dina

texts.en: Dina, 30, is married and resides with her husband, one child, and one sister in Kampong Chnang Province, Cambodia. She has been running a food store at home for over two years and is successful in her career. Her husband is a truck driver who transports dirt for sale. In order to improve her family livelihood, Dina is requesting a loan of USD 1,200 to purchase hair salon equipments for her sister to run a hair salon in order to generate more income to support the family. In the future, she would like to expand her business and support her child to study at a higher level. In addition, she plans to build a new house next year.

loan.use: to purchase hair salon equipments for her sister to run a hair salon

loan.name: Anita

texts.en:
This is Anita, 50, resident of Silang, Cavite City, Philippines. She is married to Fernando, her business partner, and is a mother to their child. She, together with her husband, manages their own household while operating the business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses and support her childâ€™s schooling.
Anita operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store, which retails groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, a Php5-worth of cooking oil, or an egg. She earns by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling by the piece. Her store is adjacent to her house. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of 800 Philippine Pesos (PHP) in sales every day.
To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a Php 50,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy groceries, toiletries, beverages, and other products needed in her business. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.
Anita hopes to grow her business in the coming years and dreams to buy a vehicle in the future. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.
* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loan.use: To pay for grocery items and products needed in her business.

loan.name: Eulalia

texts.en: Eulalia is 63 years old and lives in Dansalan, Labason, Zamboanga del Norte. She is married with 8 children. Eulalia works in the fish industry and sells fish for a living. She has been doing this for one year. She has requested a loan of 7,000 PHP to purchase two boxes of fish to sell. Eulalia has been a member of PMPC since 2011. In the future, Eulalia hopes to expand her business.

loan.use: to purchase two boxes of fish to sell

loan.name: Roselyne

texts.en: Roselyne is 41 years old, married, with five children living in Hoima, Uganda. She has a produce business and she started it with her savings from the restaurant business. She faces challenges due to high price fluctuations and high transport costs. Her family goal is to educate her children and her business goal is to expand her business to new markets. Roselyne intends to use the loan to buy beans and rice for sale.

loan.use: to buy beans and rice for sale

loan.name: Reaksmey

texts.en: Reaksmey, 23, is married and resides with her husband in Kampong Chnang Province, Cambodia. She has been working in a garment factory for over two years. Her husband is a sculptor. In order to improve her family finances, Reaksmey is requesting a loan of USD 600 to purchase a piece of farmland for growing rice in the dry season to generate more income to support the family. In the future, she would like to run a groceries store at home.

loan.use: to purchase a piece of farmland for growing rice

loan.name: Joram

texts.en: Joram is 29 years old, married and has two children, aged 2 and 4. He sells plates, slippers and polythene papers to earn a living. He has been in the business for 3 years and he describes his business environment as favorable because there is limited competition. Since he joined Faulu Kenya, Joram has been able to save his income. He hopes to be financially stable in the future. He has applied for 25,000 Kenya Shillings to buy plates, polythene papers and slippers to sell.

loan.use: to buy plates, polythene papers and slippers to sell.

loan.name: Salome

texts.en: Salome is a married woman. She has 3 children, ages ranging from 7 years to 9 years. She describes herself to be honest and outgoing. She operates a food retail business where she sells cakes. She has been involved in this business for 3 years. Her business is located at a populated and viable place and her primary customers are retail shopkeepers. She describes her biggest business challenge to be the high cost of ingredients used in baking. She will use the KES 20,000 loan to buy more ingredients for baking cakes. Within the next 5 years, Salome's business goal is to be the major supplier of cakes in the area.

loan.use: to buy ingredients for baking cakes.

loan.name: Sarorn

texts.en: Sarorn, 42, is married and resides with her husband and three children in Kampong Chhnang Province, Cambodia. She and her husband have been involved in growing rice for over twenty years. They have extensive experience and are successful in their career. Additionally, her husband is a teacher. One of her children is a construction worker. In order to have a comfortable house to live, Sarorn is requesting for a loan of USD 1000 to purchase construction materials to build a new house. In the future, she would like to raise livestock to sell and run a poultry farm to generate more income to support the family.

loan.use: to purchase construction materials to build a new house.

loan.name: Rebecca

texts.en:
Rebecca is 39 years old and lives in Malintuboan, Labason, Zamboanga del Norte. She is married with 2 children.
Rebecca works in the fishing industry and sells fish for a living. She has been doing this for 4 years. She has requested a loan of PHP 3000 to purchase more fish to sell.
Rebecca has been a member of PMPC for more than 1 year. In the future, Rebecca hopes to expand her business.

loan.use: to purchase more fish to sell by retail.

loan.name: Choeurn

texts.en: Choeurn, 34, is married. She resides with her husband and two children in Takeo Province, Cambodia. She is a garment worker. Her husband has been involved in breeding pigs for over six years. He has extensive experience and is successful in his career. One of her children is a construction worker. In order to improve her family economy, Choeurn is requesting for a loan of USD 700 to purchase more sows to breed in order to produce more piglets to sell. By doing so, her family income will be increased. In the future, she would like to expand her husband's business, renew her house and support her children to study until they get Bachelor's degrees.

loan.use: to purchase more sows to breed in order to produce piglets to sell.

loan.name: Patrick

texts.en:
Patrick is a farmer in Kitale. He is aged 52 years, and married with seven children. The first born is 18 years old, and the last born is only four months. He has been in farming for five years, and his produce of maize, sugarcane, beans, and milk are sold within the local market.
Patrick has requested a loan of 31,200 KES from Juhudi Kilimo to buy and insure a dairy cow. He says this will give a boost to his farming income and enable him to easily provide the basic family needs. He hopes to increase the number of his dairy cows.
Patrick lists animal diseases, high cost of feed, and unreliable rains as the leading challenges.

loan.use: To buy and insure a dairy cow.

loan.name: Savun

texts.en: Savun, 54, is widowed and resides with her daughter and her son-in-law in Takeo Province, Cambodia. She has been selling fried bananas for over two years, and is successful in her career. Her daughter is a garment worker. In order to improve her family economy, Savun is requesting a loan of USD 400 to purchase a Tuk-Tuk for her son in-law to run a Tuk-Tuk taxi service to generate more income to support the family. In the future, she would like to expand her business and build a new house.

loan.use: to purchase a Tuk-Tuk for her son-in-law to run a Tuk-Tuk taxi service.

loan.name: Casty

texts.en: Casty is 34-years-old; she is married and sells used clothes and shoes to earn a living. She has been in the business for two years, and has employed one person. She earns extra income from her farming activities. Since she joined Faulu Kenya, she has been able to save her income and hopes to be financially stable in the future. She has applied for 20,000 Kenya Shillings to buy second-hand clothes and shoes.

loan.use: To buy second-hand clothes and shoes.

loan.name: Bakary

texts.fr: Monsieur Bakary est Ã¢gÃ© de 34 ans, mariÃ© et pÃ¨re de 3 enfants. Elle vit dans sa famille paternelle avec ses enfants et dâ€™autres mÃ©nages. Ayant abandonnÃ© lâ€™Ã©cole au secondaire (systÃ¨me Ã©ducatif Malien), tÃ´t il embrassa le commerce de gas-oil auprÃ¨s de son oncle. AprÃ¨s plusieurs annÃ©es dâ€™apprentissage, il Ã©volua seul pour faire le commerce de gas-oil. Il mÃ¨ne cette activitÃ© depuis 10 ans et jouit dâ€™une grande expÃ©rience. Sa force de vente est due Ã la maÃ®trise du rouage de ce secteur dâ€™activitÃ©. Il vend sa marchandise au comptant Ã une clientÃ¨le composÃ©e majoritairement de chauffeurs et de revendeurs. Dans le souci de faire face Ã la demande clientÃ¨le et de faire plus de bÃ©nÃ©fice, il sollicite ce nouveau prÃªt. Monsieur Bakary envisage rÃ©aliser un bÃ©nÃ©fice mensuel de 150 000FCFA. Ce bÃ©nÃ©fice lui permettra de rembourser son prÃªt, de mener autres activitÃ©s gÃ©nÃ©ratrices de revenus. Son ambition est de construire des maisons.
texts.en:
Bakary is 34 years old, married and the father of 3 children. He and his children live with his paternal family and other households. He left school at secondary level (in the Malian education system) and started working in the diesel retail business with his uncle at an early age. After working for several years as an apprentice, he started his own diesel oil retail business. Today he is a seasoned reseller with 10 years of experience in the field. His high sales volume is due to his good understanding of how the sector works. He sells his merchandise for cash to a clientele which is mostly composed of drivers and resellers.
Bakary is requesting a new loan in order to be able to keep up with customer demand and increase his profits. He has been with Soro Yiriwaso for 36 months and has already fully repaid 3 previous loans. This will be his 4th individual loan, which he plans to use to buy 4 barrels of diesel oil. He gets his supplies on the spot.
Bakary predicts a monthly profit of 150 000 francs. His profits will allow him to repay his loan and engage in other profit-making activities. He would eventually like to build houses.

loan.use: to buy diesel oil.

loan.name: Yolanda

texts.en: Yolandaâ€™s favorite quote â€œDesire and hope will push us on toward the futureâ€ which droves her to strengthen her desire. At her age of 52, Yolanda has been managing her rice farming business for over 30 years. She is doing planting and removing of unwanted grass to minimize her labor cost in farming. She is doing all of this just to save some of her budget and spends it for the education of her three children. Yolanda is getting financial shortage in sustaining her needs in farming. She decided to borrow a loan of P50,000 to buy seeds, fertilizers, insecticides and herbicides for her farm. She hopes she can get higher income from her farming business.

loan.use: to buy seeds, fertilizers, insecticides and herbicides for her farm.

loan.name: Bourama

texts.fr: Monsieur BOURAMA est Ã¢gÃ© de 37 ans, mariÃ© et pÃ¨re de 4 enfants. Il vit dans une famille traditionnelle avec dâ€™autres mÃ©nages Ã SÃ©gou. Nâ€™ayant pas frÃ©quentÃ© lâ€™Ã©cole pour des raisons sociales, il commenÃ§a tÃ´t Ã faire lâ€™apprenti couturier auprÃ¨s dâ€™un oncle. AprÃ¨s plusieurs annÃ©es passÃ©es Ã ses cÃ´tÃ©s, il finit par ouvrir son atelier. Il mÃ¨ne cette activitÃ© depuis 15 ans. Sa force de vente est due Ã son gÃ©nie de crÃ©ation, connu de tout SÃ©gou, sa diffÃ©rence avec les autres est liÃ©e Ã son sens de crÃ©ativitÃ©. Il jouit dâ€™une clientÃ¨le composÃ©e de femmes et dâ€™hommes. Dans le dessein dâ€™augmenter son chiffre dâ€™affaire, il sollicite ce nouveau prÃªt. Il est en relation avec Soro Yiriwaso depuis 12 mois, aprÃ¨s 1 prÃªt individuel bien remboursÃ©. Il est Ã son 2Ã¨me prÃªt individuel quâ€™il compte utiliser pour acheter 1 machine Ã coudre gros fil. Il sâ€™approvisionne sur place. Monsieur BOURAMA fait ses prestations au comptant et des fois Ã crÃ©dit. Avec ce prÃªt il envisage de rÃ©aliser un bÃ©nÃ©fice mensuel de 100 000FCFA. Ce bÃ©nÃ©fice lui permettra de rembourser ses Ã©chÃ©ances avec Soro Yiriwaso et de rÃ©gler ses charges de fonctionnement. Son ambition est dâ€™agrandir son activitÃ© et dâ€™embrasser dâ€™autres activitÃ©s.
texts.en: Mr. Bourama is thirty-seven years old, married, and father of four children. He lives in a traditional family with other households in SÃ©gou. Not having attended school for social reasons, he began his sewing training early with an uncle. After several years spent at his sides, he finished by opening his studio. He has run this business for fifteen years. The strength of his sales is due to the genius of his products, known by all in SÃ©gou. The difference between him and others is linked to his sense of creativity. He enjoys a clientele composed of women and men. In the intent of increasing his turnover, he is asking for this new loan. He has been in relation with Soro Yiriwaso for twelve months, after one individual loan correctly repaid. He is at his second individual loan, which he intends to use to purchase one sewing machine for thick wire. He stocks up in the area. Monsieur Bourama does his transactions in cash and sometimes on credit. With this loan he imagines making a monthly profit of 100,000FCFA. This profit will allow him to make his repayments to Soro Yiriwaso and to settle his operating expenses. His ambition is to increase his business activities and to take up some other activities.

loan.use: to buy a sewing machine.

loan.name: Korotimi

texts.fr: Korotimi est Ã¢gÃ©e de 50 ans, veuve et mÃ¨re de 2 enfants. Elle vit dans sa famille paternelle avec ses enfants et dâ€™autres mÃ©nages. Nâ€™ayant pas frÃ©quentÃ© lâ€™Ã©cole pour des raisons sociales (parents religieux et conservateurs), elle commenÃ§a Ã faire le commerce auprÃ¨s de ses parents. Sa mÃ¨re vendait des condiments et son pÃ¨re qui avait une boutique de vente de cÃ©rÃ©ales. Riche de cette expÃ©rience empirique, elle Ã©volua seule pour mener le commerce dâ€™atiekÃ©, pomme de terre et condiments. Elle mener cette activitÃ© depuis 24 ans et jouit dâ€™une grande notoriÃ©tÃ© et clientÃ¨le, elle est trÃ¨s sollicitÃ©e au marchÃ© chÃ¢teau. Dans le souci de faire face Ã la demande clientÃ¨le et de rÃ©aliser plus de bÃ©nÃ©fice, elle sollicite un nouveau prÃªt. Elle est en relation avec Soro Yiriwaso depuis 66 mois, aprÃ¨s 3 prÃªts solidaires et 4 prÃªts individuels bien remboursÃ©s. Elle est Ã son 5Ã¨me prÃªt individuel quâ€™elle compte utiliser pour acheter de 2 tonnes dâ€™atiekÃ©. Elle sâ€™approvisionnera Ã Sikasso, Bamako et en CÃ´te dâ€™Ivoire. Korotimi vend au comptant et Ã crÃ©dit Ã une clientÃ¨le composÃ©e de femmes majoritairement. Avec ce prÃªt elle envisage rÃ©aliser un bÃ©nÃ©fice mensuel de 200 000FCFA. Ce bÃ©nÃ©fice lui permettra de rembourser ses prÃªts et de participer Ã des tontines. Son ambition est de construire une maison Ã usage dâ€™habitation.
texts.en: Korotimi is fifty years old, widowed, and mother of two children. She lives with her father's family with her children and other households. Not having attended school for social reasons (conservative and religious parents), she began to do business with her parents. Her mother sold spices and her father had a store that sold grains. Rich with this practical experience, she changed by herself to run a business selling atiekÃ© (couscous made from fermented manioc), potatoes, and spices. She has run this business for twenty-four years and enjoys a large notoriety and customer base. She is very much in demand at the MarchÃ© ChÃ¢teau. In order to cope with the demands of her customers and to make more profits, she is asking for a new loan. She has been in connection with Soro Yiriwaso for sixty-six months, and has had three group loans and four individual loans which were correctly repaid. She is at her fifth individual loan, which she intends to use to buy two tons of atiekÃ©. She stocks up in Sikasso, Bamako and in CÃ´te-d'Ivoire. Korotimi sells for cash and on credit to customers mostly made up of women. With this loan she intends to increase her monthly profit to 200,000 francs. This profit will allow her to repay her loans and to participate in tontines (investment schemes). Her ambition is to build a house to live in.

loan.use: to buy atiekÃ©, a type of couscous made of fermented manioc.

loan.name: Virginia

texts.en: Virginia is 52 years of age, married and blessed with five children. She is a house keeper and managing their rice field as well. She has been in this type of business for 30 years. With her long duration in managing a rice filed business, Virginia claims that her expertise in farming is continually develop. She uses her expertise to produce good quality of crops and harvest a high yield. Virginia is asking for a loan of P50,000 to buy fertilizers, insecticides and seeds to grow in her large field of rice. She will manage well her business, continue to be works hard in able to maintain her business and support her children needs in school and will hold a degree.

loan.use: to buy fertilizers, insecticides and seeds to grow in her large field of rice.

loan.name: Zaituni

texts.en: Zaituni lives in Kampala, Uganda. She is married and has four children, all of whom are in school. She also takes care of additional family members (sister and brother). Zaituni has a restaurant business. She has been in this business for 10 years, and she works seven days out of every week. Zaituni sells her products in a shop, by means of retail. Zaituni has requested for a loan of 1,500,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more bunches of bananas, beef, and bags of charcoal. She generates additional income through selling charcoal. The main business challenge(s) for Zaituni include transportation, thieves, and seasonality. Her goals and aspirations for her business are to own a delivery van, and also to build rental rooms. Zaituni lives in a home that she owns; she has access to electricity and piped water. Her major monthly expenses include school fees and feeding the family.

loan.use: To buy more bunches of bananas, beef, and bags of charcoal.

loan.name: Aggrey

texts.en:
Aggrey is 41 years old, and married with three children aged between 13 and 11 years. He has been in active farming for 11 years and sells his produce of maize, beans, milk, and vegetabes to the local market in his hometown of Kitale.
Aggrey has requested a loan of 62,400 KES from Juhudi Kilimo to buy and insure a dairy cow. He says this will boost his income and help him pay for the education of the children and maintain better upkeep for the entire family. He remains optimistic the farming business will continue to grow and improve the family living standards.
He mentions high cost of feed as the major challenge in farming, especially for poultry and dairy businesses.

loan.use: To buy and insure a dairy cow.

loan.name: Philip

texts.en: Philip is a businessman; he sells fruits such as oranges, bananas, and mangoes to earn a living. He has been in the business for five years. He describes his business environment as busy because he is regularly visited by customers. Since he joined Faulu Kenya, he has been able to expand his business and hopes to be financially stable in the future. He has applied for 20,000 Kenya Shillings to buy oranges, bananas, and mangoes for sale.

loan.use: To buy oranges, bananas, and mangoes for sale.

loan.name: Nathan

texts.en:
Nathan is married with five children between four and 17 years old. All of his children are in school. For the past 18 years, Nathan has been a farmer, producing maize and milk. He also runs a retail business in his hometown of Kitale in Western Kenya. Nathan's major business challenge is unreliable rainfall which limits his farming.
Nathan is requesting a 60,000 KES loan through Juhudi Kilimo to buy poultry and build a poultry housing unit. He says that the poultry business has become very lucrative will take a shorter time to provide a good return. He adds that it is easier to run a poultry business given the area's unreliable rains and notes that other farming businesses rely a great deal on water. Nathan remains hopeful that his farming business will continue to grow.

loan.use: to buy poultry and build a poultry housing unit

loan.name: Jumabubu

texts.en: Jumabubu is 55 years old, married and raised seven children. She spent 35 years working as a primary grades teacher and is known as a very goal-oriented, responsible and hardworking person. Jumabubu was able to pass her love of knowledge onto her children, who obtained higher education degrees in the fields of medicine, engineering and linguistics. Obtaining education became possible thanks to Jumabubu's family's primary business, which is fattening up and reselling livestock. This business, started in 1990 with an initial sum of 25,000 som (KGS), today yields about 15,000 som (KGS) per month. Currently, Jumabubu's business has 4 dairy cows, 15 heads of sheep, and 9 heads of goats. In order to further increase livestock headcount, Jumabubu requested a loan in the sum of 133,000 som (KGS) from the "Bai-Tushum and Partners" company to purchase additional livestock. This will allow her to expand her business and increase livestock headcount; thus, in her opinion, making the best investment of capital. In the future, Jumabubu wants to build a large house for her family.

loan.use: to purchase livestock

loan.name: Gulchehra

texts.en: Gulchehra lives in the A. Jomi district. She is 39 years old, married and has four children. Her husband is a taxi driver. Gulchehra has a secondary education. She has been involved in selling seeds and spices for over seven years. She is requesting this loan to purchase seeds. Gulchehra wants to expand her business. In the future, she plans to lease a retail outlet at a market.

loan.use: to purchase seeds

loan.name: Adama

texts.en:
This is forty-one-year-old Adama. She was born in Freetown and is married to a school teacher. For the past five years, she has sold gara lappers and Bamako lappers, which is locally dyed cloth and cloth dyed in Mali.
Adama is requesting a loan to buy materials such as ink, caustic soda, powder, white cotton cloths, and other items to produce a large quantity of gara lappers to sell. She will use the remainder of her loan to buy Bamako cloth to add to her business.

loan.use: to produce locally dyed cloth to sell

loan.name: Adama

texts.en:
Salone Microfinance Trust (SMT), a Kiva partner in Makeni, northern Sierra Leone, is very pleased to present to you Adama, a small-scale entrepreneur who has come to SMT/Kiva lenders to seek for a loan of 5,000,000 SLL.
Adama sells grocery items such as rice, salt, palm-oil (the countryâ€™s most popular cooking oil), and other products. She has been doing this business for six years now. Forty-two year old Adama is a wife and a mother of four children â€“ one in primary school, two in college and one adult. Adama has requested this loan to buy onions, salt, palm-oil, an other bulk items to add to her business.

loan.use: to buy bulk onions, salt, palm-oil, and other items

loan.name: Mumo

texts.en:
Mumo is 31 years old and is married with one child, age 7. He runs a retail shop to earn a living. He has been in this business for 2 years. He earns extra income from his farming activities. Since he joined Faulu Kenya he has been able to grow his business.
He hopes to expand his business in the future. He has applied for 20,000 Kenya Shillings to buy sugar and maize flour.

loan.use: To buy sugar and maize flour.

loan.name: Afouchata

texts.fr: NÃ©e en AoÃ»t 1987 Ã Sikasso, Afouchata est une femme mariÃ©e et mÃ¨re de 2 enfants rÃ©sidant avec son Ã©poux et leurs enfants dans une grande famille traditionnelle Ã©largie Ã Bougoula Ville Sikasso ( troisiÃ¨me rÃ©gion administrative de la rÃ©publique du Mali). AprÃ¨s avoir menÃ© beaucoup dâ€™activitÃ©s sans succÃ¨s, Afouchata sâ€™est initiÃ©e aux activitÃ©s dâ€™achat et de vente de pagnes et d'encense il y a environ 7 ans. Dans le souci de mieux satisfaire sa clientÃ¨le de plus en plus croissante, elle dÃ©cida dâ€™intÃ©grer lâ€™institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso il y a environ deux ans. AprÃ¨s un prÃªt solidaire (prÃªt du groupe) dans une association des femmes de son quartiers, elle est Ã son troisiÃ¨me prÃªt individuel et tous les prÃªts prÃ©cÃ©dents ont Ã©tÃ© correctement remboursÃ©s. Elle envisage rÃ©aliser avec ce prÃªt un bÃ©nÃ©fice mensuel de 130 000 FCFA qui sera utilisÃ© essentiellement pour augmenter son fonds de commerce, contribuer aux dÃ©penses familiales, payer les intÃ©rÃªts de son prÃªt et investir le reste dans son activitÃ©.
texts.en:
Born in August 1987 in Sikasso, Afouchata is a married women and mother of two children, living with her husband and their children in a large family traditionally extended in Bougoula Ville Sikasso (the third administrative region of the Republic of Mali). After having run many businesses without success, Afouchata learned the business of buying and selling pagnes (colorful wax cloth) and incense about seven years ago. In order to better satisfy her rapidly growing customer base, she decided to join the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso about two years ago. After one group loan in a women's group from her area, she is at her third individual loan and all of her previous loans have been correctly repaid.
This third loan will allow her to buy ten reams of pagne and incense in Bobo Dioulasso, Burkina Faso and in Sikasso, which will be sold through itinerant commerce to a group of customers essentially composed of women. She imagines achieving with this loan a profit of 130,000 francs which will be used essentially to increase the capital of her business, contribute to family expenses, pay the interest on her loan, and invest the rest in her business.

loan.use: to buy various items.

loan.name: Aminata

texts.fr: Aminata est agÃ©e de 40 ans, mariÃ©e et mÃ¨re de 2 enfants. Elle vit avec ses deux enfants dans une famille nuclÃ©aire Ã ATTbougou, un des quartiers populaires de la ville de Sikasso ( troisiÃ¨me rÃ©gion administrative de la rÃ©publique du Mali). Madame Aminata aprÃ¨s avoir menÃ© beaucoup dâ€™activitÃ©s sans succÃ¨s, sâ€™est initiÃ©e aux activitÃ©s gÃ©nÃ©ratrices de revenus notamment Ã lâ€™achat et vente dâ€™habillements (des pagnes wax, des tissus brodÃ©s) et de bijoux (des colliers en chaines et des boucles dâ€™oreilles, etc.) depuis plus de cinq ans. Elle achÃ¨te ses marchandises Ã Bobo Dioulasso (au Burkina Faso) avant de les revendre de faÃ§on ambulantes Ã une clientÃ¨le composÃ©e essentiellement de femmes. Elle est beaucoup sollicitÃ©e de sa clientÃ¨le pour la qualitÃ© de ses produits. Pour satisfaire sa clientÃ¨le de plus en plus croissante, elle dÃ©cide de rejoindre lâ€™institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso avec qui elle est Ã son premier prÃªt individuel Ce premier prÃªt individuel lui permettra dâ€™acheter 10 piÃ¨ces de pagne wax, 5 complets de tissus brodÃ©s et 10 paquets de colliers et chaines et 10 paquet de boucles dâ€™oreilles. Elle envisage rÃ©aliser avec ce prÃªt un bÃ©nÃ©fice mensuel de 90 000 FCFA qui sera utilisÃ© essentiellement pour augmenter son fonds de commerce, contribuer aux dÃ©penses familiales et payer les intÃ©rÃªts de son prÃªt.
texts.en:
Animata is 40 years old, married and the mother of two. She lives with her two children in a nuclear family in ATTbougou, a working-class district in the city of Sikasso (the third administrative region of Mali).
After having tried various business activities without success, five years ago she launched a business buying and selling clothing (traditional wax â€œpagnesâ€ cloth and embroidered cloth) and jewelry (link necklaces, earrings etc). She buys her merchandise in Bobo Dioulasso (in Burkina Faso) and then resells it as a street vendor to a clientele composed mainly of women. She is very much sought after by her customers due to the quality of her wares.
In order to meet the demands of her growing customer base, she decided to join the Soro Yiriwaso microfinance institution and is now on her first individual loan. This first individual loan will allow her to buy ten sets of wax â€œpagnesâ€ cloths, five sets of embroidered cloths , 10 packs of link necklaces and 10 packs of earrings. With this loan, she plans to achieve a monthly revenue of 90,000 West African Francs, which will be used to bolster her working capital, contribute to family budget and pay off the interest on her loan.

loan.use: to buy various merchandise

loan.name: Haby

texts.fr: Haby a plus de 53 ans mariÃ©e et mÃ¨re de 7 enfants, elle rÃ©side avec son Ã©poux, ses deux coÃ©pouses et leurs enfants en charge Ã Hamdallaye, un des quartiers populaires de la ville de Sikasso ( troisiÃ¨me rÃ©gion administrative de la rÃ©publique du Mali). Haby aprÃ¨s avoir menÃ© beaucoup dâ€™activitÃ©s sans succÃ¨s notamment lâ€™agriculture au village, elle sâ€™est initiÃ©e Ã cette activitÃ© dâ€™achat et de vente des calebasses et divers depuis plus de dix ans. Dans le souci de mieux satisfaire sa clientÃ¨le de plus en plus croissante, elle dÃ©cida de rejoindre lâ€™institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso il y a environ sept annÃ©es. AprÃ¨s 6 prÃªts solidaires (prÃªt du groupe) dans une Association des femmes de son quartier (Association BENKADI de Hamdallaye), elle est Ã prÃ©sent Ã son cinquiÃ¨me prÃªt individuel. Ses prÃªts prÃ©cÃ©dents ont Ã©tÃ© correctement remboursÃ©s. Ainsi, elle sollicite ce nouveau prÃªt pour acheter, 17 colis de calebasses Ã Tona rÃ©gion de SÃ©gou (quatriÃ¨me rÃ©gion administrative du Mali) avant de les revendre en dÃ©tail au grand marchÃ© de Sikasso prÃ¨s de la mairie centrale de la localitÃ© Ã une clientÃ¨le composÃ©e gÃ©nÃ©ralement des femmes et surtout des miniers. Elle envisage rÃ©aliser avec ce prÃªt un bÃ©nÃ©fice mensuel de 100 000 FCFA qui sera utilisÃ© essentiellement pour contribuer aux dÃ©penses familiales, payer les intÃ©rÃªts de son prÃªt et investir le reste dans son activitÃ©.
texts.en:
Haby is 53 years old, married, and mother of seven children. She lives with her husband, her two co-wives, and the children whom they raise. They live in Hamdallaye, a working-class neighborhood in the city of Sikasso (the third-largest administrative region in the Republic of Mali).
Over ten years ago, after having pursued several different business activities unsuccessfully - notably, village agriculture -, Haby began buying and selling calabash and other items.
Striving to improve the satisfaction of her ever-growing customer base, she decided to join the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso six years ago. After receiving six group-based loans as a member of an association of woman from her neighborhood (the BENKADI Association of Hamdallaye), this will now be her fifth individual loan. Her previous loans were repaid properly.
She is asking for this new loan in order to buy 17 packages of calabash in Tona, in the region of SÃ©gou (the fourth-largest administrative region in Mali). She will then resell the calabash individually at the large market near the City Hall of Sikasso. Her customers are typically women, and especially miners.
With this loan, she plans to achieve monthly profits of 100,000 FCFA, which will mainly the used to cover family expenses and pay the interest of her loan. The rest will be reinvested in her business.

loan.use: to buy calabash

loan.name: Guliza
